Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Interacting Disturbances: leaf to landscape dynamics of emerging disease, fire and drought in California coastal forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past decade, millions of trees in California and Oregon forests have been attacked by an exotic pathogen, Phytophthora ramorum, causal agent of the infectious forest disease known as sudden oak death. This destructive outbreak is occurring in redwood and oak woodland communities in the same places that have also recently experienced devastating wildfires and extreme droughts. This research will use a novel combination of molecular, greenhouse, field, and computational modeling techniques to understand how disturbances created by wildfire, drought, and infectious disease interact and impact forest ecosystems. Results are expected to illuminate how wildfire affects the persistence and spread of an invasive pathogen, how biodiversity impacts emergence of disease in disturbed vs. undisturbed plant communities, and how these interacting disturbances alter nutrient cycling in forest ecosystems.

The combined research on the ecology of infectious disease, wildfire and drought will help develop best management practices for the growing number of forested landscapes around the world that are being impacted by complex, interacting disturbances. Outreach to stakeholders will be implemented through two highly effective organizations - University of California Cooperative Extension and the California Oak Mortality Task Force. The investigators will also be actively involved with advising state, federal and International regulatory committees put in place to create policy for managing sudden oak death and other forest diseases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Meentemeyer group completed data collection and analysis in collaboration with the Rizzo and Garbelotto labs, taking the lead on developing spatially explicit multi-scale models designed to understand and predict effects of interactions between climate, fire, management, and the sudden oak death pathogen on forest vegetation and carbon. These models have provided important insights into the dynamics and impacts of sudden oak death disease, and are being actively used to guide land management.

For instance, we worked closely with our collaborators at UC Davis and Cambridge to develop a large extent model that examined possible management strategies in California, both at the current time and at the time of previous outbreaks. Our model revealed that even with extensive management, Phytophthora ramorum cannot be eradicated at this time. Had extensive management been applied in 2002, towards the beginning of the outbreak, it may have been possible to contain spread. This study highlights that quick action is critical, not only in the case of sudden oak death, but in managing other invasive pests and pathogens as well.

While eradication at a statewide scale may be unachievable, there is still much that can be done to minimize impacts and protect biodiversity at local to regional scales. To facilitate and improve stakeholder collaborations, we have developed and expanded an innovative version of the multi-host landscape epidemiological model described by Meentemeyer et al. and Cunniffe et al. (2011; 2016). Published in the journal Ecosphere, the Meentemeyer et al. paper, “Epidemiological modeling of invasion in heterogeneous landscapes” was cited in 2015 by the Ecological Society of America as a top 10 paper impacting the science of ecology. The model is now being applied in a new dynamic simulation environment, called Tangible Landscape, which allows stakeholders to explore “what-if” scenarios of management options in order to more effectively shape collaborative solutions. By offering a tangible interface with multiple ways of interaction, this technique represents an alternative to more abstract 3D computer visualization. The interactive framework now allows stakeholders to explore the effects of disease management strategies, with an eye on trade-offs between biodiversity conservation and carbon storage.

We have also developed a new epidemiological disturbance extension for the popular landscape-scale forest simulator LANDIS-II. This open source model, coupled with wildfire models, enables exploration of long-term interactions between disease and wildfire, and the cascading impacts of these interactions on forest succession, biodiversity, wildfire severity, carbon sequestration, and chemical cycling. While this extension was written with sudden oak death in mind, it is broadly applicable to any multi-host pathogen with asymmetric host competency. 

In conjunction with our modeling efforts, we have used a combination of field data and remotely sensed geospatial data to assess disease dynamics, carbon sequestration, and wildfire severity. Using these data, we have found that between-year variation in weather patterns is a strong driver of inoculum production on California bay laurel and, consequently, pathogen spillover to susceptible oak species. We have also discovered that where wildfire and disease overlap, there can be greater loss of soil nutrients. While performing these studies, we have also developed broadly applicable methods to assess wildfire severity using remotely sensed data and to fill in missing gaps in microclimate weather data.

Our lab has also been actively involved in longitudinal field measurements and conservation efforts. In collaboration with the Rizzo (UC Davis) research group, we have collected over 10 years of data on an extensive plot network covering much of the coastal forest range. We developed a hugely successful citizen science program in collaboration with the Garbelotto (UC Berkeley) group. An analysis of the data collected by the SOD Blitz citizen science effort demonstrated how citizen science can help predict the risk of emerging infectious diseases in urban ecosystems. We also reported the valuable result that – through proper education and training – our participants collected data just as reliably as professionals. Results were published in Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment in May 2015 and subsequently highlighted by John Holdren (President Obama’s senior adviser on Science and Technology Policy) in an Executive Office POTUS memo as citizen science and crowd sourcing that is advancing research on emerging infectious disease (http://1.usa.gov/1Z4T4jF).
